metaData.descriptionCS: The examinee listens to a sentence or a recorded passage, and then responds orally to comprehension questions asked by the examiner.

questions.title: Audio Calibration
questions.topInstructionsHTML: At the end of the audio track, the examinee should raise her or his hand; be sure the examinee can hear the voice clearly. Set the volume of the audio player to an appropriate level.

questions.title: Item 1. rock
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
I’m going to say a sentence, just one time. Listen carefully, and then I will ask you a question about what I said. Ready? Listen.

Read the sentence clearly with a steady pace and normal inflection.

I found a rock. (Pause about 2 seconds.) What did I find?

questions.title: Item 2. cat and dog
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
I have a cat and a dog at my house. (Pause.) What do I have at my house?

If the examinee names only one, say, ​Yes, and what else?

questions.title: Item 3. ice cream
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Ice cream is my favorite food. (Pause.) What is my favorite food?

questions.title: Item 4. inside the house
questions.topInstructionsHTML: A bird was inside the house. (Pause.) Where was the bird?

questions.title: Item 5. books and pencils
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
The boy carried books and pencils to school. (Pause.) What did he carry?

If the examinee names only one, say, ​Yes, and what else?

questions.title: Item 6. carrots
questions.topInstructionsHTML: I like carrots, but I don’t like to eat peppers. (Pause.) Which food would I want to see on my plate?

questions.title: Item 7. ball
questions.topInstructionsHTML: He picked a ball first, and then he chose a game. (Pause.) What did he pick first?

questions.title: Item 8. go to the pool
questions.topInstructionsHTML: I will go to the pool this summer, but I will not swim. (Pause.) What will I do this summer?

questions.title: Item 9. dog
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
You are going to hear a short story. Listen carefully, and then I will ask you some questions about the story. Ready? Listen.

What is Muffin?

questions.title: Item 10. jump on people
questions.topInstructionsHTML: What should Muffin not do?

answers.html: Response that indicates that Muffin should not jump up on people

questions.title: Item 11. zoo
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Where were the monkeys?

answers.html: in the trees at the zoo

questions.title: Item 12. giraffes
questions.topInstructionsHTML: What did they see before the monkeys?

questions.title: Item 13. food
questions.topInstructionsHTML: What did the monkey throw at the man?

questions.title: Item 14
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Why did one monkey jump up and down?

answers.html: Response indicating that he didn’t like the food or didn’t want to eat

questions.title: Item 15. school
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
If starting here, say, You are going to hear a short story. Listen carefully, and then I will ask you some questions about the story. Ready? Listen.

Tell me something Maya saw from the bubble.

questions.title: Item 16. on sidewalk
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Where was the bubble when Maya jumped into it?

answerGroups.answersExplanation: near her house/apartment, her steps, or front door
answerGroups.answerGroupLabel: Refers to ONE of the following:

answerGroups.answersExplanation: on the sidewalk, walk, pavement, or concrete

scoreList.label: Refers to ONE of the following:

questions.title: Item 17. it popped
questions.topInstructionsHTML: What happened to the bubble at the end?

questions.title: Item 18. d
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
How did Maya feel when she was in the bubble? Listen to these choices:

a) scared
b) sad
c) angry
d) excited

Repeat the list as needed.

questions.title: Item 19
questions.topInstructionsHTML: What is silly about this story?

answers.html: can't ride in a balloon (not bubble)
Response indicating riding/getting in a bubble or floating

questions.title: Item 20
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
​

According to the story, what are two things that a jaguar likes to eat?

If the examinee names only one animal, say, Yes, and what else?

1.conditionalText: Refers to TWO of the following:

questions.title: Item 21. in the water
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
​

According to the story, where does a jaguar find some of its food?

answers.html: Response that refers to “in the water” or a body of water

questions.title: Item 22. paws
questions.topInstructionsHTML: What part of a jaguar’s body makes it a good swimmer?

answers.html: any response that mentions legs or arms
Response that refers to feet, paws, or hands (need not refer to webbing), without mention of legs or arms

questions.title: Item 23. jungle
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
​

Where does the jaguar live?

questions.title: Item 24. bike
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
​

How was Selena getting to school?

questions.title: Item 25. c
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
​

What is the best title for this story? Listen to these choices:

a) Selena Hates School
b) An Ordinary Morning
c) Late for School
d) Selena’s Favorite Class
e) How to Ride a Bike

Repeat the list as needed.

Do not allow the examinee to change his or her response to Item 24 after hearing the choices for Item 25.

answers.html: e) How to Ride a Bike

questions.title: Item 26. she felt bad
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
​

How did Selena feel about missing her class?

answers.html: she hated it or she didn’t like it
she felt bad, sad, angry, disappointed
she was upset about missing her favorite class

1.conditionalText: Refers to ONE of the following:

questions.title: Item 27. coffee
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
If starting here, say, You are going to hear a short story. Listen carefully, and then I will ask you some questions about the story. Ready? Listen.

What woke Mom and Dad up?

answers.html: smell of what she turned on
Response that refers to coffee or the smell of coffee

questions.title: Item 28. sat down
questions.topInstructionsHTML: What did everyone in the story do at the end?

questions.title: Item 29. newspaper
questions.topInstructionsHTML: What was brought in from the porch?

questions.title: Item 30. c
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
What is the best title for this story? Listen to these choices:

a) Happy Birthday, Mom!
b) Sleeping Late
c) A Sunday Surprise
d) My Lazy Parents

Repeat the list as needed.

questions.title: Item 31
questions.topInstructionsHTML: What games did the girls usually play?

answers.html: kickball or volleyball paired with any other game

1.conditionalText: Refers to ONE or BOTH of the following:

questions.title: Item 32. didn’t like it
questions.topInstructionsHTML: How did the boys react to seeing the girls on the field?

answers.html: they started to play against the girls

1.conditionalText: Refers to ONE of the following:

questions.title: Item 33. a
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
What is the main idea of this story? Listen to these choices:

a) The girls turn the tables on the boys.
b) Football is more fun than kickball.
c) Boys are better at football than girls.
d) Girls should always play football at recess.

Repeat the list as needed.

answers.html: b) Football is more fun than kickball.
c) Boys are better at football than girls.
d) Girls should always play football at recess.
a) The girls turn the tables on the boys.

questions.title: Item 34. short signal
questions.topInstructionsHTML: What do the frogs do to avoid being eaten?

answers.html: make their croaks sound like they’re coming from different places
Response that refers to a sound that is short, small, or hard to locate
noise that is hard to track down

questions.title: Item 35. d
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
What is the best title for this paragraph? Listen to these choices:

a) Food for Thought
b) Latin American Frogs
c) Sounds Made by Frog-Eating Bats
d) All About Frog-Eating Bats

​Repeat the list as needed.

answers.html: c) Sounds Made by Frog-Eating Bats

questions.title: Item 36. by being poisonous
questions.topInstructionsHTML: How could the frogs harm the bat?

answers.html: by eating them (it’s not clear who’s eating whom)

questions.title: Item 37
questions.topInstructionsHTML: How does the bat tell whether a frog is dangerous?

answers.html: by the noise or call it makes

questions.title: Item 38. to keep warm
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Why would animals want to live in a thatch roof?

answers.html: Response suggesting warmth, comfort, or protection (from the cold)

questions.title: Item 39. slippery
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Why would an animal fall from a thatch roof during a rainstorm?

answers.html: Response indicating that the thatch was slippery, it got slick, or the animal slid off

questions.title: Item 40. c
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
What is the main topic of this paragraph? Listen to these choices:

a) thatch roofing
b) weather
c) origin of a phrase
d) care of pets in the past

Repeat the list as needed.

answers.html: d) care of pets in the past

questions.title: Item 41. 1400s
questions.topInstructionsHTML: When did people begin using the phrase, “It’s raining cats and dogs,” according to scholars?

questions.title: Item 42. a
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
If starting here, say, You are going to hear a short story. Listen carefully, and then I will ask you some questions about the story. Ready? Listen.

What book might this paragraph appear in? Listen to these titles:

a) Early Car Design
b) Computers and Design
c) Making Steel Patterns
d) The History of Detroit

Repeat the list as needed.

questions.title: Item 43. wood
questions.topInstructionsHTML: After the clay model, what material did carmakers use for the next model?

questions.title: Item 44. drawing a picture
questions.topInstructionsHTML: In the early years, what was the first step in designing a car?

answers.html: Response that refers to a drawing, picture, or blueprint

questions.title: Item 45. allows changes
questions.topInstructionsHTML: What was the benefit of using clay to make a model?

answers.html: Response indicating that clay allows changes to be made

questions.title: Item 46
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Why did they cut up the wooden model?

answers.text: use the pieces for the steel
to use to make replicas in metal

answerGroups.answersExplanation: wood pieces are used as patterns, molds, or templates
answerGroups.answerGroupLabel: Refers to ONE of the following:

answerGroups.answersExplanation: wood pieces are traced for the parts

scoreList.label: Refers to ONE of the following:

questions.title: Item 47. d
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
What did the earthquake feel like to Ming Fei? Listen to these choices:

a) like riding in an elevator
b) like riding a merry-go-round
c) like parachuting
d) like riding a wild horse

Repeat the list as needed.

answers.html: a) like riding in an elevator
d) like riding a wild horse

questions.title: Item 48
questions.topInstructionsHTML: How did Ming Fei know that he should stand in a doorway?

answerGroups.answerGroupLabel: Refers to ONE of the following:

scoreList.label: Refers to ONE of the following:

questions.title: Item 49. radio stopped
questions.topInstructionsHTML: How do we know that the power went off?

answers.html: lights went off or it got dark

questions.title: Item 50. building a frame
questions.topInstructionsHTML: According to the passage, what was the first step in building one of these houses?

answerGroups.answerGroupLabel: Refers to ONE of the following:

scoreList.label: Refers to ONE of the following:

questions.title: Item 51. animal skins
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Besides bones, what were the walls and roof made of?

questions.title: Item 52. few days
questions.topInstructionsHTML: About how long did it probably take to build a house?

answers.html: Any time interval that overlaps with 4-8 days

questions.title: Item 53. Ukraine
questions.topInstructionsHTML: In what country are these houses located?

questions.title: Item 54. b
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
According to the passage, which of these words does not describe Arabian horses? Listen to these choices:

a) swift
b) unpredictable
c) beautiful
d) gentle
e) hardy

Repeat the list as needed.

questions.title: Item 55
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Name one of the people who, according to legend, owned Arabian horses.

questions.title: Item 56
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
Name two reasons why someone might want an Arabian horse rather than another kind of horse.

If the examinee names only one reason, say, Yes, and what else?

answerGroups.answerGroupLabel: Refers to TWO of the following:

answerGroups.answersExplanation: gentle, easy to handle or train, well-behaved

scoreList.label: Refers to TWO of the following:

questions.title: Item 57. Sweden
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
​

In what country are the Ale Stones located?

questions.title: Item 58. c
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
​

What would be a good title for this paragraph? Listen to these choices:

a) Stone Structures in Sweden
b) Ancient Ship Builders
c) Viking Burial Practices
d) Viking Conquests

Repeat the list as needed.

Do not allow the examinee to change his or her response to Item 57 after hearing the choices for Item 58.

questions.title: Item 59. Otherworld
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
​

Where did Vikings believe they were taken by ship after they died?

questions.title: Item 60. a
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
Which of the following is the best title for this paragraph? Listen to these titles:

a) Ancient Roman Libraries
b) Ancient Roman Literature
c) The Invention of Cataloging
d) Books on Parchment

Repeat the list as needed.

questions.title: Item 61. unroll it
questions.topInstructionsHTML: How would you peek at the ending of a parchment book?

answers.html: Response that refers to rolling or unrolling the scroll or parchment

questions.title: Item 62
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
According to the passage, what are two ways in which ancient Roman libraries were similar to modern libraries?

If the examinee names only one idea, say, Yes, and what else?

answers.html: books organized on shelves or in cases

1.conditionalText: Refers to TWO of the following:

questions.title: Item 63. b
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
This passage is about the origin of which of the following? Listen to these choices:

a) a proverb
b) a name
c) a superstition
d) a building material
e) a university

Repeat the list as needed.

questions.title: Item 64. religious figure
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Who were the first people to wear the square-shaped hats?

answers.html: Response that refers to a religious figure or church dignitary

questions.title: Item 65. stonemasons
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Who came up with the name “mortarboard”?

questions.title: Item 66. floppier
questions.topInstructionsHTML: How did the original square hats differ from the students’ square hats?

answers.html: Response indicating that they were floppier or smaller

questions.title: Item 67
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
What two types of action brought the river back to life?

If the examinee names only one reason, say, Yes, and what else?

answerGroups.answerGroupLabel: Refers to BOTH of the following:

answerGroups.answersExplanation: education, political action, or Clearwater/Pete Seeger

scoreList.label: Refers to BOTH of the following:

questions.title: Item 68
questions.topInstructionsHTML: What is the main idea of the passage?

answers.text: any imperative such as “Save the river” or “Take care of natural resources”
how Pete Seeger saved the river
rivers can be cleaned up over time

answerGroups.answersExplanation: a general statement that nature, the environment, or a river can be restored
answerGroups.answerGroupLabel: Refers to ONE of the following:

answers.text: the Hudson is an example of how a river can be destroyed and repaired

answerGroups.answersExplanation: a specific statement that a river or the Hudson was restored

scoreList.label: Refers to ONE of the following:

BasalXNonZerosInItemGroupRule.reverseMessage: This subtest reverses after an imperfect score on this item.

observations.label: Had difficulty understanding the passages, seemed confused or said, "That didn't make sense"
Frequently responded with "I don't know" or "I forgot"
Did not maintain topic, or related responses to personal experience by saying things like "I have a new bike"
Responded to a different question than the one that was asked
